rows.title: Interactive Gamer: Choose Your Own System
rows.titleText:
Version 1.2.0: A Few Changes More Edition (11-07-21) 

There are many powers that can be found among fan fiction of all types, some of which inspired directly by separate fiction. Think a Green Lantern in Star Wars, as an example.

One of the most popular however is the concept of The Gamer: A Manhwa that involved an individual gaining the magic power to treat real life as if it were a video game, with stat & skill increases through grinding showing similar results to quite a few video games.

Perhaps you're sent to a generic genre of a world after this, with your Gamer System suited for it? Maybe you're filling this out to be sent to a specific world, or to be sent to a specific person in that world? Or perhaps you're doing this for fun, as a distraction.

Either way, feel free to go through these options, and choose the ones you wish to add!

rows.title: Rules
rows.titleText:
1. Obviously, you cannot end up with a negative number of points, only zero or above.
2. ...Aaaaaand honestly that's it. Ideally you stick to what options you choose for your Gamer System, but if you want to fudge things or add an option that doesn't exist, then feel free to price it out yourself (reasonably, I hope!), or even just ignore your limit and choose what you want!

Interactive Gamer CYOS made by Punch. Gamer System idea based on "The Gamer" manhwa webtoon by Sung Sang-Young and Sang-Ah, as well as the Generic Gamer Jump v1.1 written up by Low_Hour with permission for most of the option & description sources, some of which were taken directly. Any images used does not imply ownership of their properties obviously.

rows.title: Create Your Own System
rows.titleText:
Here's where you design the System that your Gamer System runs off of.

You start out with a selection of System Points of your own choosing, gathered from the Starting Pool Choice, and then spent in System Creation. If you don't have enough points, you can add deliberate System Flaws to some of your abilities, or if you want to modify your system to be based on a specific game/genre (or just want to have access to a specific magic/power system), you can find that in Existing Systems.

objects.title: You
objects.text: The Gamer System you're building is going towards you.

objects.title: Someone Else (Non-Powered)
objects.text: The Gamer System you're building is going to someone else, and either granting it to them if they're powerless, or replacing whatever abilities or magic they had before.

objects.title: Someone Else (Powers)
objects.text: The Gamer System you're building is going to someone else, and granting it to them without affecting any of their previous abilities. Any powers or magic they had access to prior isn't lost, but is enhanced by the System's effects. This can include characters made from a CYOA.

rows.title: Scenario
rows.titleText: Where is the system's intended recipient headed once they receive their system?

objects.title: Staying Here
objects.text: The recipient of this System is staying in their world. For the one filling this out, that'd likely mean just modern plain 'ol Earth. Hope you picked [World].

objects.title: Going to a fictional world
objects.text: The recipient of this System is transferred across universes and enters another one. It could just be an alternate universe with a slight change, or it could be a previously fictional setting made possible by the multiverse existing.

objects.title: + CYOA
objects.text:
After building this System, you can bring said system into another CYOA.

If they have an option that allows you to import another CYOA however, you must select that choice and pay it's cost, whatever it is. If they have an option that grants you a gamer system, then that option applies too.

scores.afterText: See your intended CYOA, free otherwise

rows.title: Starting Pool
rows.titleText: How much System Points do you start with?

objects.title: Builder Mode
objects.text: Gain 400 extra points, to a total of 600 SP. For when you have an idea in mind and do NOT want to be constrained whatsoever.

objects.title: Very Easy
objects.text: Gain 150 extra points, double the normal amount to a total of 350 SP. For when you want to have a easy time.

objects.title: Easy
objects.text: Gain 75 extra points, to a total of 275 SP. Plenty to mess around with if you don't want to have too hard a time!

objects.title: Normal
objects.text: Gain a total of 200 SP. Exactly the number needed to build the original System used in The Gamer.

objects.title: Hard
objects.text: Start out with a lower amount of 125 SP. Good if you want to have to take a few flaws to get your desired system.

objects.title: Very Hard
objects.text: Start out with significant loss of SP, leaving you with 50 SP. If you want a light System or to have to deal with multiple hassles for a decent one, this is the option for you

rows.title: System Creation
rows.titleText:
Here is where you directly construct the system you'll be using, whether it be adding basic sub-systems like HP or MP tracking, or adding whole new menus/commands that are often contained in square brackets [ ].

Each of these options are displayed as how they would start when you gain your system, but it is possible to gain some of these functions post-system creation. For example, if you use [dungeons] enough times you might just unlock the ability to slow time within without purchasing [Time Dilation], whether through Leveling it up enough as a Skill or through Trait purchases.

objects.title: Uncapped Growth
objects.text: One of the most important things about the Gamer System, and one that you get for free no matter what options you pick, is that of infinite potential. No matter what, you'll always improve anything about yourself to any level with sufficient time and effort. It may start getting to levels of ridiculous feats required in order to improve something, like needing to lift trains to get the required exercise needed to improve on super amounts of strength, or it may not be as easy to learn as other skills, but if you put in the right time & effort, you'll always be able to show gains in ability.

objects.title: Heads Up Display
objects.text:
Another free option, albeit one that is most in theme for The Gamer: It wouldn't be much of a Gamer ability if you didn't have a way of seeing the world like a game, now wouldn't it?

You gain a heads-up-display, as well as the ability for your System to project squares that act like pop up menus in a video game in your perspective. No one else can see these squares, or their contents of text. Whatever stats or settings your System has that can be displayed, you can navigate & view them easily, as well as interact with them through either your voice aloud or through physically touching them.

If you want, you can modify these squares, making them bigger or smaller like a window on a computer, or even move them to specific positions. This HUD also comes with a [Help] command, which can allow you to easily learn how the System you're using works, as well as what [Menus] you have access to.

objects.title: HUD+: Hands-Free Interface
objects.text:
Perhaps it annoys you that you need to say aloud that you're about to punch someone in order to activate a punching-related ability? If so, for 5 SP you can upgrade your HUD so that it works via your mind instead.

Hands-free interaction with your HUD! Perfect if you want to look at your Status Sheet without weirding people out with your poking and mumbling at stuff no one else can see!

objects.title: [Settings]
objects.text:
Something that surprisingly many Systems come without, despite being a Staple of the original Gamer System, [Settings] allows you the ability to toggle on and off whatever upgrades you have added to your System, as well as miscellaneous options you can choose. Want background music, or subtitles? Maybe want to change your System Boxes from the usual blue to a green or amber color depending on your preference for Fallout? Give them textures or make them themed after a specific video game's?

If you want to change something about the Gamer System in a way that doesn't affect game balance, or could conceivably be found in a game's settings menu? This is the Menu for you, and it's available for free if you want it.

objects.title: [Camera]
objects.text:
Or [(unregistered) Hypercam 2]. Or [FRAPS], or perhaps even [OBS].

Whatever you want to call it, [Camera] allows you to modify your perspective, whether it means changing it so you can see things as if you had a camera behind you over your shoulder, all without affecting your ability to move and interact with things from this third person perspective, or if you simply want a window in your view that always shows what's behind you.

Can be used to keep tabs on a specific location, so long as you're nearby when you place it.

objects.title: [Tips/Tutorials]
objects.text: Your System now gains the ability to tutorialize itself, as well as offer tips for you to take heed of now and then. As well, instead of having to just puzzle things out with only the commands being told to you, you also gain a manual on how your specific system works. Said manual can be summoned as either a Window or as a book in your hand.

objects.title: [Normality Filter]
objects.text: You gain a passive invisible aura that makes it so that anyone in your vicinity, at least within 10 feet, treats anything that occurs as a result of your Gamer System to be completely normal. Afterwards they might start thinking about how weird it is, but at least while they're talking to you in person, they won't find it unusual. Can be toggled on and off for everyone or changed for specific people.

objects.title: [Macros]
objects.text:
By purchasing [Macros], you gain the ability to automate actions. Starts out only allowing small/quick actions to be automated, but eventually through use it gains the ability to do both long and predictive automation. No need to place everything precisely before you do an action!

Also allows you to give yourself rules that your body will automatically reinforce and abide by once leveled high enough. Never want to kill someone directly? Set it and you'll always only hit hard enough to injure, and find yourself automatically avoid vitals no matter how hard you try.

objects.title: Gamer's Body
objects.text:
One of the staples found in the Gamer System, Gamer's Body makes it so that you have the body of a video game character. No matter how badly you are injured, you'll find that your body always works as if it was at 100%. You're able to keep going at peak ability on only a minimum of six hours' sleep, and when you do fall asleep for at least six hours, your body is completely healed.

Negative conditions like loss of limbs, illnesses or paralysis are also healed when you sleep for six hours, and are treated as status effects.
objects.imageSourceTooltip: The Gamer manhwa, Gamer's Body description

objects.title: [Gamer's Body]+: Super Sleeper
objects.text: For only 5 additional SP, you'll now find that the amount of time you require to sleep is much, much less, whether for restorative reasons or for getting the sleep you need. You only need to sleep for an hour in order to see your body healed and negative conditions fixed
objects.imageSourceTooltip: The Gamer manhwa, Gamer's Body description

objects.title: [Super Sleeper]+: Sleep Is For The Weak
objects.text: This costs 10 SP: While you still need to sleep at least an hour in order to heal and cure conditions instantly, you no longer require sleep in order to continue functioning at your fullest, like a Noctis Cape from Worm without the eidetic memory. Think about all the extra time you now have!
objects.imageSourceTooltip: The Gamer manhwa, Gamer's Body description

objects.title: Gamer's Mind
objects.text:
Another staple of the Gamer System, if Gamer's Body makes it so that your body acts like a video game character's, then Gamer's Mind grants you the mentality of someone playing a video game. Whether it be drugs, mind control, mental illnesses or anything that could effect you mentally, you will find yourself totally immune to it. Nothing can break through this immunity, and because of it you are also immune to boredom & mental exhaustion.

This doesn't just effect your mind state however, for Gamer's Mind also reinforces you emotionally: No matter what, you'll always be able to keep your cool and keep yourself from being overwhelmed emotionally. This doesn't mean that you'll find your emotions muted nor does it mean that you'll become a sociopath, it simply means that you're granted the self-control needed to always overcome it affecting your decisions, no matter how mad or saddened you might be.
objects.imageSourceTooltip: The Gamer manhwa, Gamer's Body description

objects.title: [Gamer's Mind]+ Mind Like A Steel Trap
objects.text: You'll now find that while before it would be possible for things to slip your mind, albeit never in a way that diminished your abilities, you now have an eidetic memory. You'll never forget something unless you want to specifically, and will always remember it with perfect clarity without the possibility of time fading said memory. And all for the low price of 10 SP.
objects.imageSourceTooltip: The Gamer manhwa, Gamer's Body description

objects.title: HP System
objects.text:
Another of the staples of the original Gamer System, Health Points as it stands for, the HP System acts as a meter on how healthy you are physically. Whether it starts out at a percentage or at a specific number, whenever you get hurt you'll find that it goes down, and if it ever reaches zero then you will die. You can see the HP of others if you have a HUD, and HP recovers on it's own when given enough time.

If you have HP System as well as Gamer's Body, then any injury you take, even if it's lethal, is instantly repaired so long as you have some HP remaining. As well, instead of instantly dying when reaching zero HP, you'll find that you will no longer regenerate HP for 60 seconds, after which it'll reactivate and you'll start gaining HP again.

If you purchased Levels, then you'll find your HP gets restored to full once you level up, as well as it's maximum amount increasing.

objects.title: MP System
objects.text:
Magic/Mana/etc. Points as it's known, by purchasing this staple of the original Gamer System, you gain access to mana (or whatever you call it), as well as the ability to cast magic using it. If you enter a setting or world where magic is already a thing, then it can also be used to learn spells from that system of magic, as well as cast them.  Some skills & abilities you can learn might require it, although anything involving magic always will. Used up MP will always recover when given enough time.

If you purchase Gamer's Body, then used MP will refill completely after six hours of sleep.

If you purchase Levels, then when you level up, MP is both restored and it's maximum amount increased.

objects.title: SP System
objects.text:
Stamina Points as it's known for, or even possibly Ki/Qi/Chi/Life Energy, by purchasing it you gain an extra reserve of physical stamina you can call on on top of your natural endurance, just like how HP works when paired with Gamer's Body. Using it might be required for specific skills & abilities, and used up SP will always recover given enough time.

If you purchase Gamer's Body, used up SP will recover completely after six hours of sleep.

If you purchase Levels, then when you level up, you'll both find that your SP is restored and that it's maximum amount is increased.

objects.title: Mini-Map
objects.text:
By purchasing this, you gain a 2D map which is projected on your HUD, and which is filled in through exploring the area you're in.

By default, this is always in the corner of your vision, but if you wish you can have it turned off. You can also manipulate it much like the other squares in your HUD, enlarging it in order to look at a wider area, or zooming in to peer at specific ones.
objects.imageSourceTooltip: Assassin's Creed II, map of collectibles/landmarks.

objects.title: Mini-Map+: 3D Maps
objects.text: For an additional 5 SP, your Mini-Map gains the ability to be displayed as 3D.

objects.title: Mini-Map+: Map Markers
objects.text: For yet another 5 SP, you gain the ability to mark specific locations in your Mini-Map, as well as the ability to have it automatically mark areas you've explored with markers that you would find fitting. Maybe you do want to know where every restroom in a city is?

objects.title: Food System
objects.text:
Health and Stamina can be recovered by eating food, with the recovered amount increasing by how well-prepared it is.

As well, you'll find that you no longer require food and water to survive, and if you don't want to have to use the restroom, you'll now find it to be optional.

objects.title: Threat Spectrum
objects.text:
Much like how some MMOs mark enemies with specific colors to denote how dangerous they are to you, you'll now find that a signifier appears over people's heads. Whether it's a colored symbol, a circle of color or just their name changing colors to fit it, you'll find that this spectrum of colors signifies how dangerous they are to you.

This spectrum of colors can be arrayed in whatever way makes sense to you, and can be expanded from just people to being applied to animals as well.

With Levels chosen, this signifies how over or under-leveled you are compared to an enemy, although it also takes into account how well they would fare against you. If you're immune to the cold but not heat, expect fire-users to be rated a higher threat even if you're technically the same level.

objects.title: Levels
objects.text:
One of the staple Gamer System sub-systems, no matter what, you always start out at level 1. By defeating things, you gain Experience/EXP/XP. Killing your opponent earns you more, and once you earn enough, you level up. When you level up, you'll find yourself completely healed and rejuvenated.

You can see a person's level, a rough idea on how dangerous they are, floating above their head so long as theirs isn't 50+ above your own. There's no limit to how high a level you can attain, but the higher it is, the more XP it requires you to gather.

On it's own it isn't too useful, but when combined with other systems and menus you'll find your potential growing even more.

objects.title: Relationship Menu
objects.text:
Also known as [Contacts], or perhaps [Dramatis Personae] if you want to be pretentious,  you now have a separate menu that quantifies what kind of relationships you have with specific people. It can be set up through strict categories; Friend, Friendly Acquaintance, Stranger, Enemy, etc. being examples of this. It can also be set up by a 0 to 100 percentage, with a zero signifying enemies for life and a 100 signifying a significant other with a strong connection formed with you.

Relationships may become temporarily strained, but will not deteriorate with time, and you’ll have to seriously mess up to make a relationship actively decrease. This is mind reading and probability manipulation, not mind control.

objects.title: Conversation System
objects.text: Through purchasing this addition to the Relationship Menu, you gain a new Conversation Menu: When interacting with others, you receive conversational prompts, some good, (sometimes very obviously) bad and to be avoided, with the presence of the bad ones decreasing as the relationship progresses.

objects.title: [Settings]+: [Toggling]
objects.text: Maybe you don't want to be perfectly rational for some reason, and you want to turn Gamer's Mind off for a few moments? Or perhaps you need to convince others that you aren't some kind of superhuman videogame character and need to turn Gamer's Body off in order to prove this? With [Toggling], you'll now find that the various parts that make up your System? They can be temporarily turned off for a set time, have their settings be swapped to [High], [Medium] or [Low] functionality, or just toggled on or off until you need them back on again.

objects.title: Attributes
objects.text:
One of the Gamer Staples, Attributes (also known as Stats sometimes) are a statistical measurement of your general ability, the classic examples being Strength, Dexterity, Vitality, Intelligence and Wisdom. How many attributes you have as well as what they are is up to you, but each must be reasonably powered, cover roughly the same amount of things each, and be at least possible to argue as being equal in their usefulness. You start with a reasonable number of them that represents your stats.
 
Attributes may be improved through training them, though the higher they are, the harder they are to improve this way; there is no hard limit to how high they may rise.

If you purchased Levels, then when you level up, you gain a fixed amount of Attribute Points that you can spend to improve attributes. This fixed amount is one less the number of attributes you have.

objects.title: Skills
objects.text:
A staple of the Gamer System, by spending 10 SP on this, any ability or skill you possess becomes a Skill, with it's own skill level and increasing in power and efficiency as it levels up. This is done by gaining enough experience, which is gathered by using the skill; Level 1 is maximum inefficiency, while Level 99 is the maximum efficiency you could normally get from a master of it. 

While reaching 99 means you reach the normal "cap" of the skill, you can go even beyond that and enhance a skill beyond human levels, possibly increasing it's range, quality or strength. The higher a skill’s level, the more experience required to get it to the next level. Generally, the more powerful and useful a skill is, the slower it is to level up.

Any powers, skills, or abilities you already possess are automatically converted into System skills. You may gain new skills by performing relevant actions; for example, throwing a knife might earn you the skill ‘Knife Throwing’. Skills will not deteriorate with time or disuse.
objects.imageSourceTooltip: Fallout: New Vegas, level-up screen skills

objects.title: Skills+: Prestige Skills
objects.text:
For 10 SP, when you reach the max normal level of your skill (reaching level 99 in it), it may "prestige", granting you a similar but much more powerful skill at level 1 without taking away this one or, occasionally, traits, if you purchased traits. Prestige skills might themselves prestige, but in general are harder to level up.

An example of a prestiged skill would be Knife Throwing prestiging into either Sword Throwing or into something like Throwing (General).

objects.title: Skills+: Skill Merging
objects.text:
A staple boost to the Skills System, For 10 SP you gain the ability to combine certain skills into new ones, without losing the skills that are combined. They must be at least somewhat related to each other, however.

An example would be Karate being combined with Taekwondo into Asian Martial Arts, or combining Pistol Shooting and Rifle Shooting into a general Shooting skill.

objects.title: Observe
objects.text:
A unique skill that grants you basic information about what or whoever you target with it, it's one of the Staples of the original Gamer System. The more you use it, the more information you'll find yourself uncovering when you use it. You can make it's use free, but if you make it's use cost an amount of MP or SP, it's development will go by more quickly. If you encounter someone significantly more powerful than you, with Levels denoting this as 50+ your own, information gained will be sparse.

If you purchased [Camera], then you gain the ability to use Observe through it.
objects.imageSourceTooltip: Gamer Manhwa, Black Slime's Observe results

objects.title: Skill Books
objects.text:
One of the Gamer Staples, this doesn't require the purchase of Skills, although they synergize.

If you come across an instruction manual, book or piece of data about a topic or ability, you can absorb this knowledge and gain access to it at a basic comprehensive level. Your proficiency can be improved as you would any other skill, and gaining skills and abilities this way doesn't destroy or damage the text/housing used. Many skills will require a certain amount of a specific attribute for you to be able to learn them.

objects.title: Traits
objects.text:
Traits, Perks, however you want to call them, are any positive, unusual qualities about yourself that wouldn’t really qualify as an ability or skill improvable through training or practice. Ex. accelerated rate of growth, 1-ups, poison immunity, etc. 

If you’ve purchased Levels, then the power of traits with a quantifiable effect will increase the higher your level is. Every ten levels, you will gain a new trait relevant to how you earned those levels. These traits will never be negative.

If you purchased Attributes, then you'll gain a trait when they rise at a certain level depending on how they are set up. As an example, they could do so at multiples of 50.

objects.title: Titles
objects.text:
One of the Gamer Staples, through purchasing this you now have access to Titles, which are awarded to you for doing noteworthy things. Each title confers certain abilities on you while equipped; "Dragon Slayer", earned for killing one hundred dragons, might make you particularly adept at killing more of them as an example. You may only have one title equipped at a time.

You may gain new, more powerful versions of titles you already possess for doing similar but more noteworthy things; killing one thousand of them might earn you "Dragon's Bane" as an upgraded title. You also gain the ability to see a person's title floating over their head.

objects.title: Titles+: Extra Slots
objects.text: With a purchase of 10 SP as well as Levels, instead of only having one slot to use, you gain an additional slot for every multiple of 25 in levels you possess, starting with having 2 slots at a level of 25.

objects.title: [Inventory]
objects.text:
Another one of the Gamer Staples, you have a pocket dimension arranged like a video game inventory. You can store an unlimited amount of things in it, provided each of them is something you can physically carry. Items in your inventory are placed in a sort of stasis, so that if you put a hot beverage or wet towel in it, the beverage will not grow cool and the towel will not dry; strangely, any watches placed in your inventory will keep up with the current time. While with Levels this could change, to begin with inventorying items requires contact with you.

You also gain access to an equipment screen, from which you can equip yourself with items directly from your inventory without going through the hassle of taking them out and physically putting them on.

objects.title: [Inventory]+: Living Storage
objects.text: For 10+ SP, your inventory is upgraded to be able to handle living, sapient beings being stored in there. People do not need to be willing in order for you to store them in your Inventory, although you will need to physically touch them.

objects.title: [Inventory]+: [Morrowind Placement]
objects.text: When moving objects out of your Inventory, instead of the object appearing in your hand or on the floor in front of you, you now have the ability to direct where it's placed and what kind of arrangement it has when it comes out. This also allows your ability to Inventory things to not require touch, and so long as you'd actually be able to store it into your Inventory? You now have an inventory grabbing range of 2-3 armlengths away, and easily able to be increased through leveling.

objects.title: Loot
objects.text:
If you kill something, you will gain money proportional to how dangerous the thing you defeated was. You may also gain items, sometimes magical, their power also proportional to how dangerous the thing you defeated was.

If you’ve purchased Skill Books, you may also gain skill books containing abilities relevant to the thing you defeated.

If you’ve purchased Inventory, you may have your loot appear in it automatically.

objects.title: Quests
objects.text:
One of the Gamer Staples and only for 10 SP, you may undertake quests in exchange for certain rewards upon completion, such as powerful items or notoriety. These quests can generate because of a personal goal being set, being asked to do something by another, or because something of importance is happening. Sometimes they can generate entirely randomly.

If you’ve purchased Levels , quests will always award EXP, with how much depending on the quest’s difficulty.

If you’ve purchased Traits , quests will occasionally award traits relevant to the completed quest.

If you’ve purchased Titles , quests will occasionally award titles relevant to the completed quest.

If you’ve purchased Skill Books , quests will occasionally award one relevant to the completed quest.

If you’ve purchased Classes , quests will rarely award a unique one relevant to the completed quest.

objects.title: Quests+:
objects.text: For an additional 10 SP, you receive step-by-step instructions on the things you need to do to complete individual quests. If you've purchased Mini-Map, the mini-map will display the locations you must travel to.

objects.title: Achievements
objects.text:
If you achieve certain notable milestones (ex. having 99 skills reach Level 99, killing a boss-tier opponent, or solving the "plot" of a setting you are in), then you will receive achievements along with rewards commensurate to the achievements’ difficulty. This tends to be either a suitable amount of money or an item relevant to your accomplishment (Skill-related item, the weapon said boss had, etc.)

If you’ve purchased Levels, achievements will always award EXP.

If you’ve purchased Titles, achievements will often award relevant titles.

If you’ve purchased Traits, achievements will sometimes award relevant traits.

If you’ve purchased Classes, achievements will rarely award a relevant, unique class.

objects.title: [Rosetta Stone]
objects.text: For 10 SP, you no longer have to worry about not understanding a foreign language. So long as it's spoken by a human/human-equivalent species, you'll now find that you can understand it. This doesn't mean you can speak it yourself, but at the very least you won't have issues figuring out what someone wants from you, or what they're getting from your attempts at translating your own language.

objects.title: [Rosetta Stone]+: Tongue of Babel
objects.text: Did we say understand? With an additional 10 SP you'll find that you can now speak any language known by humanity/humanity-equivalent species at least at the equivalent of someone who's spoken it for 5-10 years. We're talking sapient species, to be specific.

objects.title: [Pause] Function
objects.text:
A pause function which is added to the game, you gain the ability to pause & unpause time at will. You may not move or do anything but think while time is paused in this way, although you're still able to interact with the UI, as well as open & use other boxes like Attributes. You can open your Inventory, if you have it, but while time is paused you can't put anything in or take anything out.

If you purchased [Camera], you can look through it & move it around up to the usual range you can.

objects.title: [Pause]+: Time Speed
objects.text:
But what if a pause function isn't enough for you? You've played plenty of games where you could speed up the flow of time in order to speed through a project from your perspective, whether it be tycoon/management games or strategy ones.

This upgrade to the [Pause] System allows you to reap the benefits of this, and control the flow of time from your own perspective so that it goes faster, whether it be for a set duration, when you choose to turn it off, or even when something interrupts your current action. While time is moving faster for your perspective,  you don't suffer disorientation from doing actions at an increased time rate, and can keep up fine no matter how fast you set it. If you wanted you could use this during a work shift and find yourself zooming through 8 hours of labor in only a minute from your perspective, all without a loss in proficiency.

objects.title: [Pause]+: Slow Speed
objects.text: For another 20 SP, you gain the ability to slow time as well. Again this only happens from your perspective, and while it can give you more time to focus on a task, your movements from your perspective will be slowed as well. At least, until you can find ways to speed yourself up.

objects.title: Chatty System
objects.text:
Normally your System would be just that, a game system with no personality except for aiming to be slightly helpful. What flavor text is used is purely descriptive, and your system never seems to interact with you beyond that.

Through purchasing Chatty System however, you'll now find that your System has a personality of it's own, designed how you'd want it to be (Besides snarky and hostile) and loyal to you and your own goals. This doesn't mean that it outright talks to you, most of the time, but the text you encounter will be less a flat description and more someone else telling you about it.

objects.title: [Location Based Buffs]
objects.text: For 15 SP, and requiring Traits to function, you'll now find that some areas have their own buffs and debuffs that become applied when you enter them as a temporary trait. For example, if you entered a public gym, you might now find you gain a 20% increase in XP gains when you're training physical stats and skills there. A police station would grant buffs to policing skills while inside, a library/school/university would offer scholarly skill training buffs, etc. This only works while inside the building and any associated areas connected to it, like it's parking lot or anything fenced in.

objects.title: [Fast Travel]
objects.text: Requiring Mini-Map to be purchased, this option grants you access to a Fast Travel system: If you've visited a location, you gain the ability to teleport back to it, unless it's a restricted area you don't have access to. You will never telefrag anyone with it, and it must be an area you've seen and at least somewhat remember. Traversing like this can either take the appropriate amount of time, or be instant, and either way has enough range to cross the world if needed. It also takes into account local transportation that you have access to, so if you have say a car you cross more ground, doubly so with a plane/helicopter, etc.

objects.title: [Physics]
objects.text:
You sure you want this option? It wasn't meant to be... Well, I can make a few fixes if you're sure!

This system adds a physics engine to your game. Normally this would do nothing, since all worlds have their own laws of physics, but this System-added one tends to glitch out. I patched out the more annoying ones, but if you focus intently and try to glitch it a certain way, you'll find that any glitches you can think of? it now works. Tribes Skiing, Source Surfing, bunnyhopping, backwards longjumping, if you can glitch it in an Elder Scrolls game, Fallout game, Source game or similarly glitchy game, you just might be able to do it yourself now. Any wall's a door if you have a bucket!

objects.title: Magic System
objects.text:
A mage’s best friend. With the MP System and Skills, you become capable of picking up any magic spells you come across, but if you want something a bit more friendly to the System or are going to a world without magic, this is the purchase for you.

Built into the Gamer System is a magic system specifically designed for it. You start off with a bunch of basic spells, and as you learn more spells and grow more proficient with them, you’ll automatically become capable of more advanced ones. The kicker? There are no arbitrary limits, no ranks of magic beyond which you can never advance; you will never stop learning.

objects.title: Ki System
objects.text:
A fighter’s best friend. Where magic manipulates and relies on mana for fuel, this option does the same for ki, also called qi, chi, or life energy, here represented by SP. Basic techniques include enhancing your physical aptitude, but with enough training, you will be able to use it to enhance spells or even concepts, achieve feats of legend like parting an ocean or eluding death itself, or even manipulate the ki of others to strengthen, weaken, or control them.

You start off with a bunch of basic techniques, and as you learn more techniques and grow more proficient with them, you’ll automatically become capable of more advanced ones. The kicker? There are no arbitrary limits, no ranks of ki manipulation beyond which you can never advance; you will never stop learning

objects.title: Crafting System
objects.text: You can sacrifice certain items to create from them a greater whole. Craft potions, forge weapons, build battlements, and more. You may also break down items into raw ‘crafting components’ of appropriate rarity to the item being deconstructed, that can then be used to craft other items of appropriate rarity.

objects.title: [Gacha]
objects.text:
Once per day, you may make a spin of the [Gacha], winning a random amount of money, a randomly useful item, or, depending on your purchases, levels, attribute points, skill books, titles, traits, or unique classes. Also, sometimes you may win extra gacha spins.

The range for how valuable the possible rewards are is immense, but the average will always be slightly useful to you, no matter how powerful you are, and no matter how worthless, will never be something negative. On some days you will win a stick, on others the Infinity+1 Sword.

As this feature is entirely dependent on luck, who knows how it would be affected by something like a luck stat?

objects.title: [Store]
objects.text: There is a store accessible through the UI through which you can spend money to purchase useful items, as well as, depending on your purchases, levels, attribute points, skill books, titles, traits, unique classes, gacha spins, and temporary buffs/bonuses. Cost naturally scales with the value of the commodity in question. You may also sell or trade loot and items to this store.

objects.title: [Dungeons]
objects.text:
A staple of the original Gamer System, you may enter and exit ‘IDs’, or ‘Instant Dungeons’, at will. For flavor, you may have this be a creation and destruction of IDs, as in original canon, or you may have them already exist naturally, with this ability merely granting access to them. By default, IDs are barren reflections of the real world, and you will appear in it in the same location you enter it from the real world, and you will return to the real world in the same location that you exited the ID. You can bring others into the ID with you, provided they consent.

With practice, though, you can cause IDs to generate non-sapient monsters to fight and train against, and the more proficient you grow, the more powerful you can make the generated monsters; once you defeat enough monsters, a boss monster may appear. With practice, you can cause the ID to take the form of new locales like forests, mountains, tundras, or even D&D-style dungeons. With practice, you can even cause time to pass faster in the ID than outside in the real world, allowing for more efficient training.

objects.title: [Dungeons]+: Time Dilation
objects.text:
For another 20 SP, you no longer have to worry about being stuck in a dungeon for a week when it was supposed to be a couple hour thing. While inside a Dungeon, time is either paused outside of it, or slowed down. Whichever it is, it's the one that is more convenient for you at that time.

Time between Worlds works similarly, if you purchased it: If you want no time to pass, then you can spend a month or year in one world and return to find not even a second has passed, and any aging you went through reversing. If time does pass while you're in a World, then you can trigger it so that you're automatically returned when a certain amount of time in the real world or game world passes.

objects.title: [Dungeons]+: [Worlds]
objects.text:
A step beyond Instant Dungeons, you now gain the ability to enter worlds that you know exist so long as you have access to it's source. Commonly this is attained through having a copy of it, ex. gaining access to the world of Metal Gear Solid: Peace Walker by having a copy of the PSP disc & using it as a catalyst, or entering the world of Harry Dresden by using a copy of one of the Dresden Files books.

You enter the world at the start of the media's source: If you entered the book Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets for example, then you would find yourself in the world on Harry Potter's twelfth birthday, either appearing near or at the Dursley's home.

objects.title: [Party] System
objects.text:
A Gamer Staple, known as [Party] under your System, you may invite others to form a ‘party’, though no more than nine people excluding yourself. Party-members may communicate to each other through text entered through the UI and will be automatically alerted when a fellow party-member is under attack. Party-members are not subject to friendly fire, and need not worry about accidentally harming one another.

If you’ve purchased HP System, MP System, SP System, Mini-Map, Threat Cursors, Levels, Attributes, Skills, Traits, and/or Titles, then party-members will automatically gain access to those as well for as long as they’re members of the party. Any improvements to level, stats, attributes, or skills will be retained even after they’ve left the party.

If you’ve purchased Levels , then you can mess around with how experience is distributed among the party. For example, you could make it divided equally, divided according to level favoring those of a higher level, divided according to level favoring those of a lower level, or divided according to who did how much damage.

objects.title: [Party]+: Party-wide XP
objects.text: ...However, if you want to ignore that last bit and are willing to spend an extra 10 SP, then everyone in your party earns the full XP earned from any encounter so long as they contributed in some fashion to the encounter being defeated

objects.title: [Guild] System
objects.text:
You may invite others to join a ‘guild’, with no upper limit on members. You may send guild wide notifications from any distance. All guild-members may send private messages to other guild-members, and you may selectively grant and revoke the right for other members to send guild-wide notifications. You may design a symbol of the guild, which guild-members can automatically apply to any items they possess.

You may do administrative things like instituting a tax on money earned by all guild-members, setting aside the money gathered this way for purposes such as funding the guild’s goals or buying guild-wide bonuses from the store.

If you’ve purchased Titles, then your guild may also gain titles from accomplishments of the organization as a whole, with any member able to equip them. You are also capable of assigning guild-only titles, which are supplementary titles that don’t count towards the limit of how many a person can have equipped, and which award special benefits while acting in the service of the guild and its interests depending on their rank.

If you’ve purchased the Store , then guild-members may also access it, using their own funds or any guild funds to which you’ve granted them access.

objects.title: [Guild]+: Guild-wide Party
objects.text: If you have already purchased [Party] System, then with another payment of 10 SP you can grant your Guild members the benefits of the Party System's effects on party-members, except for experience sharing.

objects.title: Classes
objects.text:
For 20 SP, as well has having purchased Levels, you have access to Classes, ex. Bard, White Mage, Black Mage, Rogue, Barbarian, Knight, etc. Each class has a ‘tree’ of branching abilities that suit the class, and each time you level up, you may select one of the next available abilities on the tree to learn.

You may change classes at any time, retaining any abilities you’ve gained from them, at the cost of resetting your level to 1 for the new class, with the obvious cascading effects for things that rely on your level, like HP, MP, SP, or traits; if you switch back to an old class, your level will change back to what it was when you switched out of it.

objects.title: Classes+: Retainment
objects.text:
By purchasing this for only 10 SP,  you will retain the boosts to HP, MP, and SP even after switching classes, and traits will work based on the total levels you’ve ever had, rather than how many you currently have.

Think how levels work in Dungeons and Dragons, with a character always being at level 10 even if you're multiclassed into two separate classes with 5 levels in each.

objects.title: Classes+: Prestige Classes
objects.text: For a purchase of 10 SP along with Classes, once you have enough levels in certain prerequisite classes, you will gain access to much more powerful ‘prestige’ classes.

objects.title: [Private Room]
objects.text: For 20 SP, and with a purchase of Inventory, you gain the ability to make a door open up to a pocket dimension provided by your System, whether it be through a magic System-provided key or just willing it to happen while touching the door's knob. Instead of items going into your Inventory, they can be sent into here, still in stasis until you will them not be. By default it takes the appearance of an open warehouse space with concrete flooring, fluorescent lights, and an approximate area of 40,000 square feet.

objects.title: [Private Room]+: [Player Home]
objects.text: Private Home. Now instead of just being a warehouse, you gain the ability to make a door open up into a separate pocket dimension provided by your System. This one leads to a private home, in this case matching the size of a small apartment in a major US city. However, if you purchased Levels, then the more you use or put XP into this sub-system, the more your home will be upgraded in size and quality. With enough time and investment what started out as a cramped 1-2 room apartment can become a mansion of grand size and furniture.

addons.title: Guild Hall
addons.text:
If you take Player Home along with having [Guild] System, then your Guild gains it's own Guild Hall pocket dimension that can be entered in the same manner as Player Home by anyone who is a part of the guild. Permanent portals can be made outside to specific locations by the head of the Guild, and parts of the Guild Hall can be set so that only Guild Members can enter them. The size of the Guild Hall starts out as a big room with a few side rooms for each member of the Guild, and money or XP can be contributed by all members to make it bigger and more lavish.

While you have final say on who's allowed in and where, along with the general design aesthetic the Guild Hall takes, other Guild members could dedicate money and points into adding to it's layout or leveling it up.

objects.title: [Summons]
objects.text: If you defeat something, whether it be by killing it, or incapacitating it (knock it out, force it to concede, etc.), you gain the ability to summon it. The bigger it is, the more MP it costs you to summon and maintain it, but anything summoned follows your commands and orders whether said aloud or given through your mind. You also gain the ability to see whatever they see.

objects.title: [Summons]+: Control Summon
objects.text: For 20 more SP, you gain the ability to control summons directly, although initially being stuck only able to do one at a time. With enough levels you'll gain the ability to control & keep track of more than one creature at a time.

objects.title: [Character Creation]
objects.text: You get to completely re-design your own body, including race/species & sex/gender. You can choose whether people who know what you looked like before find the change normal, unusual, or forget about you entirely. This also affects records that recorded you, like your license or birth certificate, so if you turn into an elf or a frog-folk you'll at least be covered by that. Might want to take Normality Filter if you go for something nonhuman though!

objects.title: [Character Creation]+: Avatar Slots
objects.text: For 10 additional SP, you can gain an additional slot which you can use to store a different "Avatar" of yourself. This essentially means you can have two different redesigns under the parameters of [Character Creation] at once, along with the ability to swap between them. While they can have slightly different stats, for the most part they're only minor differences/improvements. You may have 10 Avatar Slots maximum.

objects.title: [Extra Lives]
objects.text: A System that costs 30 SP, instead of dying, you now find that you come back to life at the last place you either died, consider your home, or the last place you slept. These extra lives come from a collectable of some sort, and you can gain more lives by collecting them. On the flip side, they must be extremely rare, and I do mean rare. You could pick mushrooms of a green hue and with white spots, but it has to be a rare amount of white spots for example.

objects.title: [Multiplayer] Mode
objects.text: A pretty powerful System to have as part of your Gamer System, [Multiplayer] allows you to summon a perfect duplicate of yourself, along with the ability to unsummon them at will. As a perfect clone, they have your mindset, memories, and full Gamer System available to themselves. Fortunately they are always subservient to you, and will follow your commands if you give them one, although since they'll remember what you would tell them, odds are they won't need prompting. If they die, then the [Multiplayer] system will be on cooldown for 24 hours.

objects.title: Save Slot
objects.text:
You can ‘save’ a point in time, to which you can return at will, and may do so automatically upon death. When you use a save, it is only your own mind that is ‘sent back in time’; you do not retain any physical improvements you’ve made, and any allies you may have do not travel back with you, although mental improvements do stick around.

You may save new points in time at the cost of replacing the old one, and you can only have a single one saved. Once a save is used, it is deleted.

A save slot has a title, along with the date, time, & your stats at the time of saving. It also includes an image of what you were looking at during that time.

objects.title: Extra Save Slot
objects.text:
You can spend 5 extra SP along with Save Slot in order to gain additional save slots to use. You can choose while 'saving' which slot is taken over, and at a point of death you can choose between any of the Save Slots to 'reload'.

If you wish you can also designate a save slot as one that cannot be deleted, which saves immediately upon you gaining the Gamer System. Perfect if you want to have a pseudo New Game+ to muck around with.

objects.title: [Cheats]
objects.text:
...Wait a second, how did you get access to this? With this, you have access to what's commonly known as the Developer Console in a game, and now it includes your own Game.

Simply put, if you input things correctly, you can now warp reality a certain way. Give yourself money, change the Race and Class of another, change how gravity affects you. And those are just the minor things you could fiddle with, did someone say select the final boss and type "Kill"?

Very expensive and set at a height of 1000 points for obvious reasons, but then again, only cheaters could possibly get this perk anyways.

rows.title: System Flaws
rows.titleText: Perhaps you want more power for your System, but don't have enough System Points to build what you want? If you wish to, you can add deliberate flaws to your system, in return for more System Points to be used.

objects.title: Limited Inventory
objects.text: Your inventory is limited in some way, either through having a weight system based on how much you can carry, or a volume limit that every item needs to fit into.

objects.title: Limited Quests
objects.text: You may not have more than 10 quests active at a time.

objects.title: Limited Skills
objects.text: You have hundreds of skills and yet only seem to use 3? Not anymore. By gaining this Flaw for 20 SP you're now only able to have 20 skills in total. If The Dragonborn could get by with 18 you'll be fine with 20.

objects.title: Limited Skills-: Even More Limited
objects.text: Of course, for another 10 SP you can halve that amount, and only have access to 10 skills at once.

objects.title: Cooldown
objects.text: Requiring Skills, any active skills you possess — that is, skills that must be deliberately activated to use — have a cooldown before they can be activated again. This cooldown will decrease as you level up the skill.

objects.title: No Higher
objects.text: A skill’s level cannot exceed 99; once you get there, it’s done improving.

objects.title: Book Burning
objects.text: Requiring Skill Books, the process of gaining access to the skill contained within a skill book damages or destroys it. It can do anything from simply pop out of existence with nary a sound, stick around with the text or data inside now illegible, or even fall apart into dust or outright combust away with a flash.

objects.title: Not A Pachinko Parlor
objects.text: For 20 SP, half the cost of Store and Gacha, you only gain one restriction: You can't sell items you earn under Gacha into the Store.

objects.title: Plugged Leak
objects.text: Requiring [Party] System and Levels, if there’s more than a difference of ten levels between the highest-level party-member and the lowest-level party member, then experience is automatically distributed according to who did how much damage.

objects.title: RNG
objects.text: Requiring Levels and Attributes, instead of getting a set number of attribute points when you level up and getting to pick which attributes you invest them in, you gain a random number of attribute points when you level up, and they are automatically placed in whichever attributes you made the most use out of.

objects.title: Inescapable
objects.text: Requiring [Dungeons], there will often be certain conditions preventing you from leaving Dungeons until those conditions are met, ex. you can’t leave until you’ve killed a certain number of monsters, or until you've obtained a heavily defended item.

objects.title: Inescapable+: Worlds
objects.text:
For double the SP that Inescapable gives you, the effect is now applied to entered Worlds as well. Until you fulfill some specific conditions, you will not be able to leave the World.

This can involve solving the "plot" of said world, whether it be the standalone World's or that of the entire franchise said World is a part of. Ex. Stopping Solidus' plan in Metal Gear Solid 2, or taking out The Patriots themselves somehow, and thus ending the threat Solidus is plotting against.

objects.title: One Class Only
objects.text:
You are restricted to a single class, and you cannot switch out of it.

If you purchased Prestige Classes, then rather than gaining prestige classes once you have enough levels in the prerequisite classes, you will automatically prestige into a more powerful class upon reaching Level 99 in your current one.

objects.title: Save Slot-: Save Points
objects.text: For +10 SP, you no longer gain the ability to save wherever you want. Instead, you must use special Save Points to do this. These appear as either halos of light on the ground, as a floating object that is slightly transparent, or some other unique sign that denotes a Save Point. One always appears next to your current bed, and others appear at the very least within landmarks and important locations. Whenever you load a same you appear at the Save Point at the time you saved your Game.

objects.title: Save Points-: Rarer Save Points
objects.text: Did I say landmarks and important locations? For another +10 SP that definition changes to mean they're never closer than a mile apart.

objects.title: HP Casting
objects.text: Any abilities you have that would require a source of fuel such as MP or SP instead are deducted directly from your HP, even if you didn’t buy HP System; to use any of your powers with a cost, it’ll mean hurting yourself.

objects.title: HP Casting-: All Abilities
objects.text: ...But if you purchase this extra flaw in return for an additional 10 SP, this applies to even abilities without a cost.

objects.title: System Source
objects.text: Normally, you just have your System, with no known source that could be subverted or damaged by others. By choosing this Flaw however your System has a specific source, and the above is no longer true. For 10 SP it involves something small or loose, such as nanomachines or an energy source in your body. Something that normally can't be damaged but someone figuring it out could possibly manage it.

objects.title: System Source+
objects.text: For another 10 SP it must be something more conspicuous. Examples would be a necklace, a crystal, or an organ in your body like a benign tumor in your brain.

objects.title: System Source~: Book-Based System
objects.text: For 20 SP, while your HUD can still function, when it comes to editing or seeing your stats and information windows, your System's Source is now found in a book that you summon. This effectively means that unless you have some way of slowing down time or speeding yourself up, you won't be able to modify your stats or look at your options in the middle of a fight. Whether or not other people can read what text and pages pop up in your System Book, or if it looks like illegible scribbles/an unknown language/blank to them, is up to you, unless you took Screenpeeking.

objects.title: [Physics]-: [Havok Physics Engine]
objects.text: Unfortunately for you, whatever fixes that were applied to the [Physics] System have broken, and the annoyances that you would normally have been able to avoid are now simply part of your System. Now instead of having purely beneficial glitches to use at your leisure, now you'll have to contend with the daily annoyances of anything you put down deciding to shoot up randomly, or sliding across the table slowly as if friction were a mere suggestion. More dangerous glitches could be encountered, but hopefully you'll have abilities and skills that can deal with them by the time they start popping up.

objects.title: Infectious System
objects.text:
For 20 SP being granted to you, people close to you have the chance to gain their own copy of your Gamer system, and anyone you spend a lot of time near is almost guaranteed to get it after a few days of being near you.

They gain a lesser version of the system, almost like they chose EVERYTHING At Level One, which has to have it's more expensive options unlocked over time. However, they can eventually gain the full version once they've made those unlocks. As well, because of how easily it spreads, you now have the ability to deliberately infect someone else with your System, whether nerfed as normal or full. Once it happens you cannot take it back/revoke it.

objects.title: Infectious System+: Full System Infection
objects.text: For another 20 SP, they gain access to the same system you had at the start instead of having to unlock the full system over time.

objects.title: Nemesis
objects.text:
There's something out there, or someone, whose goal is simple: Whatever it is you're doing, whether you're using your System for good, evil, or simply for yourself, they'll specifically work against you to do the opposite.

Whether it be another Gamer diametrically opposed to you or some outsider entity whose existence literally is to mess with Gamers, they intend to at best annoy you, at worst work to prevent whatever you work towards. They can be defeated for good, but they're at least as powerful as your own System allows you to be.

objects.title: Chatty System-: Snarky System
objects.text: Requires taking Chatty System. Now you'll find your system to be somewhat snarky and sarcastic, giving you lines that could be funny or rude depending on how you'd take that sense of humor. Expect to be called a nerd for leveling your intelligence.

objects.title: Snarky System-: Hostile System
objects.text: Did we say snarky and sarcastic? Now it's downright mean-spirited and an asshole. I hope you got Gamer's Mind...

objects.title: Profanity Filter
objects.text: Unfortunately, it seems like your Game was changed to be a bit more fitting for a young Player. Now you no longer can curse, the word coming out as something else (Fuck into duck, hell into heck, etc.) If you're using the word correctly (Saying hell to talk about Hell, calling a female dog a bitch, etc.) then the censorship isn't applied. This doesn't affect hearing other people curse.

objects.title: Profanity Filter~: Toggle
objects.text: If you want this to change when you're finally of age however, this profanity filter can be toggled once you reach at least 16 years of age, or whatever is considered a legal adult for your case, whichever is shorter. However, this filter now affects your hearing of curses  while on as well. If you entered the world of Worm with it on, prepare to laugh when most of Skidmark's sentences come out as bleeps or changed cusses.

objects.title: Profanity Filter-: Family Friendly Censorship
objects.text:
It seems the ESRB took notice, and they want things to be more "family friendly". Because of this, you'll now have to deal with a bit more censorship. For example, if you see anyone naked they'll have their bits pixellated so that you can't see, and yes that includes yourself. Any attempts to have sex will have things fade to black until the deed is done too.

Gore? This is America's ESRB, gore's fine!

objects.title: No Training
objects.text: Training does nothing for you, the only way you'll be able to improve your skills is through allocating the points into them.

objects.title: Levels-: EVERYTHING at Level One
objects.text:
This ability does exactly as it describes,  and forces EVERYTHING in your System to start out at level one, or at least it's equivalent. What this means is that even your basic systems start out much weaker than how they normally would, although they can be leveled to their former heights through using them enough to level enough times. They can even potentially grow further beyond in their boons.

For each System purchase you've made that is listed below, you must take that many times this flaw and apply it thusly:

addons.title: Gamer's Body
addons.text: If you purchased Gamer's Body, then the system starts out only allowing you to recover and heal instantly from sleeping, while also only preventing your Attributes from decreasing through disuse if you have that system. If your right arm is broken, while you can heal that through sleeping, you will not be able to punch with it without the realistic effects that would occur from doing so.

addons.title: Gamer's Mind
addons.text: If you purchased Gamer's Mind, then it only grants you the immunity to mental effects, while also preventing Skills from getting worse through disuse if you have that system. You can still be overwhelmed emotionally and are not initially shielded/reinforced emotionally.

addons.title: MP System
addons.text: If you purchased MP System, then you'll find learning a single spell takes an hour of concentration, and attempts at creating custom spells will take the same amount of time.

addons.title: SP System
addons.text: If you purchased SP System, then it acts much the same as it would for MP System, except for Ki techniques.

addons.title: Mini-Map
addons.text: If you purchased Mini-map, then instead of getting a 2D map of your location that you can zoom in on & resize, your mini-map acts as a motion detector for anything within 25 meters.

addons.title: Dungeons
addons.text: If you purchased Dungeons, then creation or entry into one can take an hour of concentration.

addons.title: Worlds
addons.text: If you purchased Worlds, then entry into a World can take an hour of concentration.

addons.title: Private Room
addons.text: If you chose [Private Room], instead of starting out as a decently sized warehouse room, your Private Room now manifests as a broom closet you can enter into.

addons.title: Player Home
addons.text: If you chose [Private Room]+: [Player Home], Instead of being a cramped apartment you'd find in a major city, your Player Home starts out as a pod bed you'd find in a Japanese capsule hotel.

addons.title: Summons
addons.text: If you chose [Summons], you must kill, not defeat, a quantity of a creature in order to be able to summon it. An example would be 10-20 rats in order to summon a single one, or 3-5 bears for the same. The requirement scales down based on the creature's strength.

objects.title: Sociopath's Mind
objects.text: Remember when we said that Gamer’s Mind didn’t dampen your emotions, just gave you enough control to not be overcome by them? Well, unfortunately, that’s not true anymore: for 20 SP, you can’t feel emotions at any intensity significant enough to compromise your thought process. You can feel somewhat sad, but you won't shut down in tears as an example.

objects.title: Sociopath's Mind-: Emotionless Gamer
objects.text: ...But if you want another 20 SP, you can purchase this to find that you can’t feel emotion at all unless it’s very low-intensity or only in brief flashes.

objects.title: Screenpeeking
objects.text: Before, your windows/squares/Systems would be only visible to you, your screens being projected into your eyes like an Augmented Reality lens and not actually in front of you. Now, this is not the case: Whenever you have a window open, you're actually projecting it in front of you, and everyone else will be able to see this.

objects.title: Mark of The Gamer
objects.text: Pick a spot on your body and a symbol of any kind, whether it be a game controller, circle with flame, sideways Omega, or a rune drawn on your left hand. Whenever you use your System in a meaningful way, not including your HUD but whenever you interact with your windows/squares/Systems, you'll find that your symbol glows in some fashion. Whether it glows blue with a pale mist like The Outsider's Mark, burns like hellfire or ash, or even just turns completely black, it looks unnatural and obviously unusual. Easily hidden, although the glow will slightly show through clothing.

objects.title: Mark of The Gamer-: Altered Body of The Gamer
objects.text: 40 SP Instead of just having a symbol that glows or becomes noticable, parts of your body start changing to reflect your System's activation. Maybe your hands and feet turn into a lightly green glowing metal, your eyes glow blue while your floating hair gains dark and light blue highlights? It has to be pretty dang obvious that you've got some kind of power active.

objects.title: Lost Memory
objects.text: For only the loan of 40 SP, you'll find that your memories of before gaining your System to be more fuzzy, the further back they are. You'll remember the broad strokes, as well as the most important events, but the names and details about who they were will be loosened. You'd recognize your brother and remember that one time you both got in trouble, but you wouldn't know their personality/name, nor the hard tacks about what happened specifically.

objects.title: Lost Memory-: Amnesiac Gamer
objects.text: For a further 40+ SP, you will lose all of your memories from before gaining your System. You would effectively be starting out as a blank slate, with no memories to guide you except for what skill and personality you already have. I hope the 80 SP was worth the potential identity crisis.

objects.title: Beta Tester
objects.text: The one who gave you this system did so under a specific stipulation: You can use this system, break it and become as powerful as you want, but in return you're supposed to be helping them test it out in the wild. You can now expect to be in semi-regular contact with the Patron of your System, although on your end you'll have to send in reports on how you're finding the system. Any complaints about the setting, like is it too dark and edgy? Found an exploit, and not sure if it's intended or not? Feeling the hurt from not having something and wanting to make sure that's known? Make sure to let them know, every week or month!

objects.title: Endboss
objects.text:
You have to kill some kind of extremely powerful enemy. If it exists in the world you're in you can choose a fitting target, like Salem in RWBY, Zion/The Warrior for Worm or the Chaos Gods if you woke up in a Warhammer world. If you don't start in a world that has one, then a vague eldritch entity will take the place for your world.

This will be a tough battle for sure.

objects.title: That Time I Got Reincarnated As A Gamer
objects.text: 100 SP, they're all yours... So long as you're fine with losing your human form. Instead, you'll now find yourself in a much weaker body, whether that be something like a slime, a rat, a spider, a cat, or some similarly weak monster/animal. While you could eventually level yourself enough to change your race and look somewhat human, like a humanoid slime or a rat person, it'll be a process and not be something you can do for a long time. Your System's scale of stats changes to fit your new form, so being at 100 Strength as a rat might mean you can lift a human child: Superrat, not superhuman!

rows.title: Existing Systems
rows.titleText:
The Gamer is a fairly unique system, with the potential to make it's own spells or Ki abilities, but if you're wanting abilities from a specific setting, or to modify your System to fit a specific game's, then this is the category you're looking for.

Mini-Systems are for granting yourself magic powers or super abilities from a specific source of fiction. Using them requires having access to the MP system, although whether it always costs MP to use or only for higher-skill abilities is up to you.

Template Systems are for modifying your System to fit a specific game's parameters, while also granting you unique sub-systems/abilities from that game.

Genre Systems are like Template Systems, except instead of being based on a specific game, they're based on a genericized genre of game.

rows.title: Mini-System
rows.titleText:
Purchasing each of these options grants you said magic/super abilities at a beginner level, and adds it in as a system of magic or ability you have access to.

In General: You can learn how to do more things either through buying knowledge in [Shop] either straight up or through books/scrolls, winning them in [Gacha], or through self-study.

objects.title: Magic (The Irregular at Magic High School)
Random Superpower
objects.text: Requires use of link, must take whatever given: https://powerlisting.fandom.com/wiki/Special:Random

objects.title: Card Magician (Pick A Card - Worm/See No Evil - DC)

rows.title: Tech Trees
rows.titleText:
Much like how Mini-System deals with magic and power systems, Tech Trees is the tab you use when you simply want to build and maintain technology found from a specific setting.

While an option might list a specific discipline, enough use, leveling, specific traits, etc. might unlock other options found from that setting.

objects.title: Tinker of Fiction
objects.text:
Whichever options you pick below, you effectively become an unshackled and improved Tinker Cape from the Worm web serial written by Wildbow. You gain an instinctive knowledge of what you need to craft anything related to your specializations, as well as the slight ability to manipulate matter while creating with it in order to make the process quicker. You can enter Tinker Fugues where you build anything related to your chosen specializations perfectly and with no flaws. Besides the perks of being a Tinker, you actually fully understand the princibles behind your chosen techs, and can innovate/combine different tech trees effectively.

This does not give you a Shard companion, no, it's System provided.

rows.title: Template Systems
rows.titleText:
Maybe you feel the System you're building is a bit too generic and plain for you. You've played video games before, and you know if you could you'd pick one specific one and just have your System run like you were playing that one. Template Systems is the category for just that.

Also known as System Packages, one of the most important pieces of information for this: If a System is mentioned in one of the Template System options, especially capitalized, then purchasing it grants you that system albeit with it working as described. Purchasing Fallout means you don't need to buy Attributes, but they *will* be the S.P.E.C.I.A.L System whether you want them to be or not.

objects.title: Template System: Fallout
objects.text:
With this System Package you find that your system tends to act like it would in the later Fallout games. Instead of Attributes your system runs under the SPECIAL System, which stand for Strength, Perception, Endurance, Charisma, Intelligence, Agility and Luck. 10 is the level cap for this, and the Skills run under a cap of 100. Every time you level you gain a few skill points that you can put into your skills, which are themed for your setting. However, every other time you level up you gain a Perk, which is themed for your setting and can act like a Trait/Title in respect to it's potential buffs/debuffs.

You also gain a Faction Menu that allow you to see how a faction you know about views you, as well as individuals of note. Another more interesting system added through this package is that of the Settlement System: If you own an area, whether it be legally or through de facto ownership instead of de jure, you gain the ability to instantly build, store or break down items and buildings so long as you're nearby and have the resources required either on your person or in-storage. Perfect if you want to start your own settlement or just wish to decorate your house with ease.

objects.title: Template System: Disco Elysium
objects.text:
Now this is a unique System Package compared to the others on offer: The biggest part is that your Skills are now sapient, and you'll find them becoming more chatty and talkative the more levels you put into them. The maximum cap of skill points you can put into your skills is based on your Attributes of Intellect, Psyche, Physique & Motorics' levels. If you have a low Physique, don't be surprised to hear Vitality's skill cap will be low.

Your skills represent broad enough concepts that it'd end up being useful for three occupations/types of people in general. Visual Calculus (A skill for putting together what happened through environmental clues) for example would be good for "Forensics Scientists, Tactical Fighters, & Math-Minded People". Another System you unlock through purchasing this is the Thought Cabinet, letting you consider an ideal/thought which acts much like Titles or Traits, with temporary effects while a Thought is being considered and then new effects for when the Thought was cabineted for long enough.

objects.title: Template System: The Sims
objects.text:
A System Package that's unique for it's utility at living a "normal" life, the long and short of it is that you can now do anything that you could do in The Sims' Build, Buy and Living Modes.

For instance, you can put yourself into an automatic mode where your body mechanically follows actions you chose in the order you tell them to, like controlling a Sim would work. Perfect for chores like dishes or gardening! While in this mode, actions work like they do in The Sims: If you cook food, expect to stir a bowl of red sauce only to pour it onto a plate and have it instantly become your desired dish, or to spend an hour splattering paint against an easel only for it to slowly morph into your desired art piece over time.

Along with this you gain a boost in your ability to learn Skills, as well as the ability to perform object interactions that would be possible in the Sims, whether or not you're in the automatic mode listed above. An example of this would be directly selling items in your Inventory for money, automatically buying ingredients you need and having them appear before you while cooking/tinkering on a project, or even selling paintings after finishing them direct from the easel. If you ask someone to leave your home, they'll find themselves immediately walking out, and if you ban someone from coming inside they'll find the doors and windows no longer opening for them no matter if they have the right key or not.

You gain a HUD that lists both your own and others' emotional states, as well as the reasons they're/you're feeling that way. Traits are also part of this, as well as a Lifestyle/Aspiration Rewards system that rewards you with items or traits for fulfilling Aspirations and Whims.

On top of all this is of course the ability to build/edit a house instantly so long as you own the land or have permission, purchase furniture and move it with your mind, etc. The Sims grants you a lot of functions!

objects.title: The Sims+: Supernatural Stuff Pack
objects.text:
The prior system doesn't give you access to the sort of supernatural phenomenon you'd find in The Sims, only that which could be considered normal and occasionally futuristic.

This upgrade to the base Sims Template System changes that. While previously Life States are locked to whatever is found in the world you inhabit, now you have the chance to shift from human into something unusual so long as you get the right item/interaction with someone, whether it be a Vampire biting you or brewing a Bottled Curse of the Lycan and drinking it.

Purchasing this also grants you access to any of the spells that a Sim can have access to, whether or not you technically have the Spellcaster Life State set as your own.
objects.imageSourceTooltip: The Sims 3: Supernatural, snipped from box art

objects.title: Template System: GURPS
objects.text:
Yes, we're going there.

You gain access to two systems: [Character Sheet], and [Books]. [Character Sheet] does exactly as described, and shows your stats (Skills, Attributes, Titles, Traits, all with Levels) as they would be aligned for a GURPS character. [Books] allows you to look through any of the books used in 4th Edition GURPS, which is the version of GURPS that your System now runs on.

Any significant action you perform, whether it be finishing Quests, gaining Achievements, killing something, etc. grants you Character Points which you can spend on anything found within [Books]. It might not sound like much, but think about it: GURPS is a system purposefully genericized enough that it could run any kind of setting. That means that if you can think of any kind of power, ability, skill, or even negative versions of each, there's likely a way to give it to yourself if you gain enough Points and find the correct way to word it in your Sheet.

For example, want an [Inventory] without purchasing it? Payload (+40% Reflexive +50% Cosmic) [2] would allow you to store at least your Basic Lift ((STxST)/5 lbs, or what you can lift with one hand over your head) divided by 10 of anything in an extradimensional space for only 2 points, and would scale with every 2 points you put into it. And because of Reflexive and Cosmic, while it doubles the price from 1 to 2, your "Inventory" activates by reflex and doesn't require having space inside your body to work, ignoring that rule of Payload and working anyways.
